Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicant's refugee claim due to lack of subjective and objective fear and inadequate state protection analysis?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa and sought refugee status based on fear of spousal abuse in Jamaica.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed; case referred back to a different panel of the Immigration and Refugee Board for re-determination.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Overstayed visa and failed to leave Canada upon expiration of authorized stay
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of spousal abuse in Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility findings; reasonableness simpliciter for state protection findings
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Credibility of fear, adequacy of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found lack of subjective and objective fear; court found this assessment patently unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony of applicant, documentary evidence on country conditions in Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 97 and Section 98 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Crimes.Application_Basis: Refugee claim based on well-founded fear of persecution due to domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Threats from ex-partner, history of domestic abuse, response of Jamaican authorities
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee and protection from removal
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Standard of review depends on nature of issue: credibility vs. state protection
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored key evidence showing credible fear and inadequate state protection
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted to new panel
Crimes.Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of serious harm due to domestic violence upon return to Jamaica
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant overstayed visa after entering Canada lawfully and claimed refugee status fearing return to abusive partner
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Board failed to properly consider or address relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA (failure to comply with conditions or expiry of status)
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Selective use of evidence, disregard of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal status beyond authorized period
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient and unreasonable evaluation of applicant’s evidence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board’s conclusions were not supported by the evidence and lacked proper analysis
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to account for documented patterns of domestic violence and ineffective police response in Jamaica

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicant's claim for refugee protection based on fear of spousal abuse?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant feared returning to Jamaica due to spousal abuse and applied for refugee protection in Canada.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case referred back to the Board for re-determination by a different panel.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's refusal of refugee protection
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant under removal order seeking relief based on risk upon return
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remaining in Canada after issuance of a removal order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of spousal abuse and lack of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility findings; reasonableness for state protection analysis
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Credibility of threats, effectiveness of state protection mechanisms in Jamaica
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging procedural fairness and substantive assessment
Crimes.Review_Standard: Reasonableness and patent unreasonableness depending on issue type
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board dismissed fear; court found such dismissal unreasonable given supporting evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Personal testimony, country condition reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
Crimes.Application_Basis: Refugee protection claim grounded in gender-based persecution and state inability to protect
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: History of abuse, police inaction, ongoing threats from ex-partner
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and recognition as a protected person
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Review standards vary by nature of legal issue
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board misinterpreted country conditions and overlooked critical evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: High risk of domestic violence and potential fatality if returned to Jamaica
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant remained in Canada despite removal order due to fear of life-threatening domestic abuse
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Inadequate consideration of documentary evidence on systemic failures in Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44(1) of IRPA (failure to comply with removal order)
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Misinterpretation and selective reliance on country information
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to depart Canada as required by removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review final decisions of the IRB
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Flawed analysis of both personal and country evidence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board’s conclusion was unreasonable due to insufficient engagement with evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to recognize pattern of domestic violence and institutional neglect in Jamaica
